title: Feedback Is a Superpower
description: Strength grows where feedback flows. This chapter will dig into how lifters and leaders alike depend on real, raw, and regular feedback to improve. Whether it's a bar path breakdown or a postmortem from a launch, feedback is the force multiplier — but only if you're strong enough to seek it.

links.name: Stefi Cohen's Coaching Evolution
links.summary: Explores Stefi Cohen's evolving approach to training, blending isolation and compound movements, and emphasizing adaptability — a model of feedback-driven progression.

links.name: Motor Learning and Coaching Cues
links.summary: Outlines effective coaching cues in baseball, including directional visual prompts like "turn the flashlight," to support motor learning through immediate feedback.

links.name: Fitbit Sleep Score Anxiety
links.summary: Explores how Fitbit's sleep score feature, intended to empower users, inadvertently created stress and confusion as people began to fixate on a single metric rather than holistic health.

links.name: RPE and RIR in Strength Training
links.summary: Outlines how Rate of Perceived Exertion (RPE) and Reps in Reserve (RIR) offer subjective yet critical feedback for athletes — emphasizing that true progress requires honest self-assessment, not just numbers.

links.name: Target Canada Collapse
links.summary: A detailed account of how Target's expansion into Canada failed due to systemic issues, misread data, and ignored frontline feedback — resulting in one of the most expensive retail failures in history.

links.name: Elastic's Acquisition of Endgame
links.summary: Provides context on the Endgame acquisition and the iterative, feedback-driven strategy that shaped its product approach.

links.name: Slack's Origins and Internal Tool Pivot
links.summary: Details how Slack emerged from an internal communication tool at Tiny Speck, developed during the creation of the game Glitch, and evolved through continuous internal feedback loops.

links.name: Slack's Product Philosophy
links.summary: Reveals how the team behind Slack ritualized internal feedback and refined the tool based on daily use, long before realizing it could become a standalone product.

links.name: Figma's Culture of Real-Time Feedback
links.summary: Figma's built-in commenting and mock review workflows enable low-friction, high-impact feedback loops across product and design.

links.name: Lovable AI and Creative Iteration
links.summary: At UOttOhack, the Lovable team demonstrated how rapid iteration with AI tools can accelerate app development, enabling real-time feedback and collaborative creativity.

links.name: Duolingo's Onboarding and Retention Strategies
links.summary: Analyzes Duolingo's onboarding process, highlighting how personalization and gamification contribute to user retention and engagement.

links.name: Duolingo's Feedback-Driven UX
links.summary: Duolingo uses micro-interactions and behavioral cues to offer real-time encouragement and course correction within its language learning platform.

links.name: The Problem with Listening to Metrics
links.summary: Highlights how organizations often misinterpret data due to cognitive biases, bad proxies, or unexamined assumptions, leading to poor strategic decisions.

links.name: Product Managers Must Talk to Users
links.summary: Marty Cagan explains why user conversations are not optional for PMs, and how constant, intentional feedback is essential to product leadership.

links.name: The Medici Effect
links.summary: Frans Johansson's concept of intersectional innovation emphasizes the value of early, diverse input — the "share early" principle is foundational to adaptive feedback.
